sourceDesc.bibl: The Epic Poem in The Peripatetic John Thelwall Judith Thompson Detroit, Michigan Wayne State UP 2001
Typopictoromania in The Derby Manuscript John Thelwall

projectDesc.p: Our text is Typopictoromania, an epic fragment that was to have been part of a much longer poem. It is epic like Dryden, satirical like Pope, critical like Blake; the fragment reveals the beginnings of a poem that was to use a grand yet cartoonish battle, one between the types of Caslon’s print house and the brushes of Boydell’s Shakespeare Gallery, as an opportunity to ridicule the abuse and abasement of poetic language during the revolutionary period in England. While the poem was never finished, what has survived—a preface, proposition, an invocation, a first canto, part of a second, and a few random fragments, together totalling close to five hundred lines of poetry—are both aesthetically and historically relevant to those interested in the early romanticism of the revolutionary period. While Thelwall claims that he initially intended to write a complete poem, its unfinished nature puts it in the same historical camp as Keats’ Hyperion and Coleridge’s Kubla Khan, texts that are paradoxically whole in their incompleteness. Furthermore, the poem is of particular import for Thelwall scholars; appearing in both The Peripatetic of 1793 and in the later Derby Manuscript, the poem bookends Thelwall’s career. The two copies differ in a great many minor respects, particularly in punctuation, but a significant amount of major variations, where the later Thelwall has rewritten entire lines, are also present; a thorough study of the differences may be valuable for scholars interested in the development from the younger to older Thelwall. Thus, our task is to present a complete and accessible reading copy of the poem, showing a preference to the most recent and hitherto unpublished version (the Derby Manuscript) and including all important variations in editorial notes and additional yet important material in appendices. Furthermore, our TEI coding will ensure that scholars have access to all variations between the texts for the sake of comparison.

app.lem: Genius of Britain!—not that power who strung
app.rdg: Genius of Britain!—not that power who strung
Genius of Britain!—Not that power who strung

app.lem: A Hampden’s arm, and urg’d his patriot tongue—
app.rdg: A Hampden’s arm, and urg’d his patriot tongue—
A Hampden’s arm, and urg’d his patriot’s tongue—

app.lem:
Not she who warm’d a Sydney’s, Russell’s soul,John Hampden (1653-1696) was so admired by Thelwall that he named his second son after him. An anti-monarchist who wanted to reinstate a republic, Hampden was arrested for allegedly taking part in the Rye-house plot, but later acquitted. Algernon Sydney (1623–1683) and William, Lord Russell (1639-1683), both anti-monarchists arrested with Hampden for the Rye-house plot, were unlike him, executed. Thelwall named his eldest son after Sydney (Algernon Sydney Thelwall). That the poet does not invoke the Genius that inspired these three men, all of whom Thelwall greatly admired for their political views, makes clear the satirical nature of what is to come; the Genius of Modern Britain, as it is named in the prefatory material of P (see Appendix II), pales in comparison to that of the past.
Comma after Sydney’s retained from P: absent in DM.
app.rdg: Not she that who warm’d a Sydney’s Russell’s Soul,
Not she that warmed a Sydney’s, Russel’s soul,

app.lem: Corruption’s tyrant progress to control—
app.rdg: Corruption’s tyrant progress to controul—
Corruption’s tyrant progress to control—

app.lem: Ere yet pretended Patriots, bought and sold,
app.rdg: Ere yet pretended Patriots, bought and sold,
Ere yet pretended Patriots, bought and sold,

app.lem: Made public barter of their votes for gold;—
app.rdg: Made public barter of their votes for gold;—
Made public barter of their Votes, for Gold;—

app.lem: Ere Freedom’s Representatives, by name,
app.rdg: Ere Freedom’s Representatives, by name
Ere Freedom’s representatives, by name

app.lem: Lauded despotic power, unaw’d by shame;
app.rdg: Lauded despotic power, unaw’d by shame;
Lauded Despotic Power, unaw’d by shame;

app.lem: In public Senates (fir’d with frantic rage,
app.rdg: In public Senates fir’d with frantic rage,
In public Senates (fired with frantic rage,

app.lem: Which not the tears of friendship could assuage)As with the couplet at line 15, the parentheses, despite being absent in DM, are retained from P for this couplet. We have chosen to retain the punctuation of P because there is a formal echoing that is lost without the parentheses; the mirroring of the Senates and the driveling dotards is less obvious without the parentheses.
app.rdg: Which not the tears of friendship could assuage;
Which not the tears of Friendship could assuage)

app.lem: Blacken’d each name that, true to Freedom’s cause,
app.rdg: Blacken’d each name that true to Freedom’s cause
Blacken’d each Name that, true to Freedom’s cause,

app.lem: Dar’d plead for Nature’s violated Laws;—
app.rdg: Dar’d plead for nature’s violated Laws;—
Dar’d plead for Nature’s violated Laws;—

app.lem: Ere yet, grown grey in party’s sordid train
app.rdg: Ere yet grown grey in party’s sordid train
Ere yet, grown grey in Party’s sordid train,

app.lem: (Where who like them the clamorous throat to strain?)
app.rdg: (Where who like them the clamourous throat to strain?)
(Where who like them the clamorous throat to strain?)

app.lem: Wild driveling dotards (fir’d with sacred hate

rdg.add: Wild driveling dotards, fir’d with sacred hate

app.rdg: Wild, driv’ling Dotards (fired with sacred hate

app.lem: Of all who held what they upheld of late)In addition to the retention of parentheses (see note 19), commas have been removed from after dotards (present only in DM) and late (present in both editions) to maintain the formal echo.

rdg.add: Of all who held what they upheld of late,

app.rdg: Of all who held what they upheld of late,)

app.lem: Damn’d all the honors which a glossing Tongue,Thelwall spells honors in the DM with the American spelling without the u, but in the P the British spelling is used.
app.rdg: Damn’d all the honors with which a glossing Tongue,
Damn’d all the Honours with a glossing Tongue,

lg.l: Practis’d in fraud, and with persuasion hung,

app.lem: Still with the rotten heart at prudent strife,
app.rdg: Still with the rotten heart at prudent strife,
Still with the rotten Heart at prudent strife,

app.lem: Had purchas’d with the lie of a whole life;
app.rdg: Had purchas’d with the lie of a whole life;
Had purchas’d with the Lie of a whole life;

app.lem: Renounc’d all principle, and bared the heart,
app.rdg: Renounc’d all principle, and bared the heart,
Renounc’d all Principle, and bared the Heart,

app.lem: So long conceal’d from view with painful art:
app.rdg: So long conceal’d from view with painful art:
So long conceal’d from view with painful Art;

app.lem: Threw off the mask, so long with credit worn,
app.rdg: Threw off the mask, so long with credit worn,
Threw off the Mask, so long with credit worn,

app.lem: And chang’d respect for pity and for scorn;
app.rdg: And chang’d respect for pity and for scorn;
And chang’d respect for Pity, and for Scorn;

app.lem: To Bathos div’d for culinary wit,Spelling of culinary corrected from cullinary: spelled correctly in P
app.rdg: To Bathos div’d for cullinary wit,
To Bathos dived for culinary wit,

app.lem: Made e’en the Stews and Billingsgate submitLondon’s primary fish market located at the docks. The British Library notes that it was noted for the coarse language used by the women who worked there and their propensity for gossip. This explains the poet’s later description of the women’s voices containing the Classic graces of the vulgar tongue (line 18 of Canto Two).
app.rdg: Made e’en the Stews and Billinsgate submit
Made e’en the Stews and Billingsgate submit

app.lem: With sheer scurrility, and blushing own Spelling of scurrility corrected from scurility: spelled correctly in P.
app.rdg: With sheer scurility, and blushing own
With sheer scurrility, and blushing own

lg.l: Their claim to mount the Shrew’s contested Throne;
Thence soaring high, or thinking that they soar’d,

app.lem: The Realms of Beauteous and Sublime explor’d,—A reference to Edmund Burke (1729-1797) and his A Philosophical Enquiry into the Origin and of Our Ideas of the Sublime and the Beautiful (1757). Much of this stanza refers to Burke: see Introduction.
app.rdg: The Realms of Beauteous & Sublime explor’d,—
The realms of Beauteous and Sublime explor’d,

app.lem: Pluck’d down the Stars, and thought those stars too poor
app.rdg: Pluck’d down the Stars, & thought those stars too poor
Pluck’d down the Stars, and thought those stars too poor

app.lem: (Moon-struck themselves!) to deck a Royal Whore,Moon-struck retained from P. While the word is certainly not struck in the DM, since there are many more than five letters and the final three are definitely ch’d, we are unable to decipher with absolute certainty what word it is. We believe it might be stretch’d, but we are unable to find any explanation of what moon stretch’d might mean. Thus, we have retained the line from P for certainty’s sake.
app.rdg: (Moon stretch’d themselves!) to deck a Royal Whore,
(Moon-struck themselves!) to deck a Royal Whore,

lg.l: Because she chanc’d the Gallic Throne to share,

app.lem: For which (to Dorset thanks!) she brought an Heir.In P, this line reads, To which (to Dorset thanks!) she brought an Heir. Exclamation mark retained from P: absent in DM.
app.rdg: For which (to Dorset thanks) she brought an Heir.
To which (to Dorset thanks!) she brought an Heir.

app.lem: —But why with plurals thus mankind disgrace?
app.rdg: —But why with plurals thus mankind disgrace?
—But why with plurals thus Mankind disgrace?
When even these times produce but one so base
When even these times produce but one so base.

app.lem: Genius of Britain prompt my Epic Theme—
app.rdg: Genius of Britain prompt my Epic Theme—
Genius of Britain! prompt my Epic theme—

app.lem: Not thou who nurs’d by Heliconia’s streamIn P, the line reads, Not thou who, nurs’d by Heliconia’s stream, (in reference to Mt. Helicon, home of the muses in Greek mythology); it is possible Thelwall removed the commas for rhythmic purposes, to ensure no punctuation broke the flow of the line.
app.rdg: Not thou who nurs’d by Heliconia’s stream
Not thou who, nurs’d by Heliconia’s stream,

app.lem: Taught one illustrious British Prince to feel
app.rdg: Taught one illustrious British Prince to feel
Taught One Illustrious British Prince to feel

app.lem: A noble love for Learning’s sacred weal,—
app.rdg: A noble love for Learning’s sacred weal,—
A noble love for learning’s sacred weal,—

lg.l: To Sage and Bard that patronage supply

app.lem: Which pimps and black-legs now alone enjoy,—Thelwall went through many possible variations before settling on black-legs. In P, the line says pimps and fiddlers, but fiddlers is nowhere to be found in the DM. Instead, pathics, gamblers, and panders are all written in as possible words, but are crossed out. According to the 1811 Dictionary of the Vulgar Tongue, black-legs is a term for a gambler or sharper on the turf or in the cockpit: so called, perhaps, from their appearing generally in boots; or else from game-cocks whose legs are always black. According to the OED, a pander is a pimp, a fiddler is a swindler or a cheat, and a pathic is the passive partner in homosexual … intercourse. One can only wonder why Thelwall spent so long trying to find just the right term here.
app.rdg: Which pimps & pathics panders gamblers black-legs now alone enjoy,—
Which pimps and fiddlers now alone enjoy,—

app.lem: And having freed the Land from foreign foesIn P, the line reads, And, having freed the Land from foreign Foes,: see note 31.
app.rdg: And having freed the Land from foreign foes
And, having freed the land from foreign Foes,

lg.l: Rous’d him to purge it from the darker woes

app.lem: Of savage ignorance; and Science rear
app.rdg: Of savage ignorance; and Science rear
Of savage Ignorance, and Science rear,

app.lem: At once by his Example and his care;—
app.rdg: At once by his Example and his care;—
At once by his Example, and his Care—

app.lem: Not thou who urg’d the godlike Alfred’s soul
app.rdg: Not thou who urg’d the godlike Alfred’s soul
Not thou who urg’d the Godlike Alfred’s soul,

app.lem: (Virtue his race, immortal fame his Goal!)Spelling of immortal corrected from imortal: spelled correctly in P. In addition, comma retained from P; absent in DM.
app.rdg: (Virtue his race imortal fame his Goal!)
(Virtue his Race, Immortal Fame his Goal!)

app.lem: With reverend Sages to devote his prime;—Prime retained from P. It is unclear whether the word is prime or time in the DM; it looks like it reads time, but it could just as easily be a hastily scribbled prime. For certainty’s sake we retain prime, but one may wish to read it as time.
app.rdg: With reverend Sages to devote his time;—
With reverend Sages to devote his prime,—

app.lem: Ere Dicers Boxers Swindlers curs’d the clime;
app.rdg: Ere Dicers Boxers Swindlers curs’d the clime;
Ere Caterers, Boxers, Swindlers, curs’d the Clime—

app.lem: Ere yet the Turf alone had charms; ere yet
app.rdg: Ere yet the Turf alone had charms; ere yet
Ere yet the Turf alone had charms—Ere yet

app.lem: Rooking was Science, Jockeying was wit;
app.rdg: Rooking was Science, Jockeying was wit;
Rooking was Science, Jockeying was Wit—

app.lem: For Studs ere Splendid Palaces arose,—
app.rdg: For studs ere splendid Palaces arose,—
For Studs ere Splendid Palaces arose,—

app.lem: Where Steeds and Grooms in idle rank repose,
app.rdg: Where Steeds and Grooms in idle rank repose,
Where Steeds and Grooms, in idle ranks, repose,

app.lem: Consuming more than Gallia’s haughty Lord,
app.rdg: Consuming more than Gallia’s haughty Lord,
Consuming more than Gallia’s haughty Lord,

app.lem: Her fourteenth Louis, spent to deck that boardLouis XIV (1643-1715), King of France.
app.rdg: Her fourteenth Louis, spent to deck that board
Her Fourteenth Louis, spent to deck that board

app.lem: Where Taste and Science found a sure retreat,
app.rdg: Where taste and science found a sure retreat,
Where Taste and Science found a sure retreat,

app.lem: And all the Wits of Europe had a Seat!—
app.rdg: And all the wits of Europe had a Seat!—
And all the Wits of Europe had a Seat!—

app.lem: Not thou who taught mellifluous Pope to sing
app.rdg: Not thou who taught mellifluous Pope to sing
—Not thou who taught mellifluous Pope to sing,
Plum’d Shakespeare’s, Milton’s, Dryden’s daring wing;
Plum’d Shakespeare’s, Milton’s, Dryden’s daring wing,

app.lem: Ere whining Pratt, the pink of common place,Samuel Jackson Pratt (1749-1814) was a poet whose sentimental literary persona rarely carried over into his personal life. Thelwall often criticized him. In P, Pratt is spelled with only one T. According to the OED, the word prat meant, in the late eighteenth century, A trick; a piece of trickery or fraud; a prank or practical joke, and it was also slang for the buttocks. Judith Thompson believes that by spelling it with one T Thelwall was making a deliberate joke at Pratt’s expense. Whether or not his choice to include the second T in the DM, long after Pratt’s death, shows a change of heart on Thelwall’s part is up to the reader to decide.
app.rdg: Ere whining Pratt, the pink of common place,
Ere whining Prat, the Pink of Common Place,

app.lem: Pour’d forth long nothings with so soft a grace,
app.rdg: Pour’d forth long nothings with so soft a grace,
Pour’d forth long nothings with so soft a grace,

lg.l: Made Sentiment so languishingly creepFrom Made Sentiment (line 63 of Invocation) until as well as they (line 174 of Invocation), Thelwall has pasted in pages from the P. Thus, only minor changes are made by Thelwall. Since Thelwall clearly had access to a copy of the P from which he could take pages, it is strange that he chose to handwrite some sections of the poem without making major changes to them: the first twenty lines of the Invocation, for instance. One imagines he could have cut and pasted the whole poem into the DM and then made his minor changes in the margins (as he does at line 130 of the Invocation). One can only speculate as to the reasons for this decision. Editorial note: Words in full caps have been edited so as to only have first letter capitalized, and any other major changes marked with notes.
To the charm’d Heart, as charm’d it quite to Sleep;

app.lem: Made Sympathy thro’ two long Cantoes shine,
app.rdg: Made Sympathy thro’ two long Cantoes shine,
Made Sympathy thro’ two long Cantoes shine,

lg.l: Without assistance from one feeling line,

app.lem: And fair Humanity—so soft—so sweet—
app.rdg: And fair Humanity—so soft—so sweet—
And fair Humanity—so soft—so sweet—

app.lem: Drawl thro’ dull pages to the hundredth sheet;
app.rdg: Drawl thro’ dull pages to the hundredth sheet;
Drawl thro dull pages to the hundredth sheet;

app.lem: Drew meek Morality with such a Grace,
app.rdg: Drew meek Morality with such a Grace,
Drew meek Morality with such a Grace,

lg.l: With such a simpering, lack-a-daisey Face,
Such water-gruel Sweetness, one would swear
She suckled Fools, and chronicled small beer.

app.lem: —Ere yet quaint Fopperies from the Italian SchoolThe poetry of the Italian School was characterised in terms of its theatrical displays of emotion, overt sensuality, heavily stylised language and complex sound structure (Broadhead 577).
app.rdg: —Ere yet quaint Fopperies from the Italian School
—Ere yet quaint Fopperies from the Italian School

lg.l: Threw in forc’d Extasies each Rhyming Fool;According to the OED, extasy was an acceptable spelling well into the eighteenth century. Thus, we have retained the spelling.
Bit, like the Gad Fly, Widows, Wives, and Maids,
With frantic bleat to scare the tuneful Shades,
Where self-thought Poets, deeper bit than they,

app.lem: To their wild bleat, return’d as wild a bray!—
app.rdg: To their wild bleat, return’d as wild a bray!—
To their wild bleat return’d as wild a bray!—

app.lem: Ere Della Crusca, darling of the World!Used first as a pseudonym by Robert Merry, who was involved with a romantic relationship with Hannah Cowley, the term Della Crusca was used, after 1795, to label all of the poets following the Italian school. For more see Alex Broadhead’s The Della Cruscans: A Survey of the Criticisms and Resources. In DM, Thelwall has written in an additional L to turn the DE LA of the P to DELLA.
app.rdg: Ere DELLA CRUSCA, darling of the WORLD!
Ere de la Crusca, darling of the World!

lg.l: The random Gaze of Moon-struck-madness hurl’d
Thro’ the wild Wilderness of blooming Suns,From Robert Merry’s Ode to Anna Matilda.
And Scenes which Common Sense indignant shuns;
Where Popularity, (debauch’d, and led
By that old Bawd, hight Puffing, to his Bed,)
Brought forth a Swarm of misshaped Monsters, more
Than ever spawn’d on Nilus’ antic Shore;—
Monsters, to nurture which, in happy Hour,

app.lem: Dame Cowley waken’d in the Muses Bow’r—
app.rdg: Dame COWLEY waken’d in the Muses Bow’r—
Dame Cowley waken’d in the Muses Bow’r—

lg.l: That Bow’r in which, strew’d by her Angel Hand
With Poppies cull’d in Morpheus happy Land—
Morpheus! inspiring God of modern Themes!Morpheus is the ancient Greek god of dreams.
The Patron blest of Poesy and Dreams!—
That Bow’r, in which the balmy-soothing Pow’r
With partial fondness, oft, at Evening Hour,
(Attention pillowing her reclining Head)
The sweetest Slumbers o’er her Senses spread;
While crowded Theatres, by Fate’s decree,
First clapp’d, then yawn’d, then snor’d as loud as she.

app.lem: Genius of Britain!—by what Title grac’d—
app.rdg: GENIUS of BRITAIN!—by what Title grac’d—
Genius of Britain!—by what Title grac’d—

app.lem: Fashion or Folly, Vanity or Taste—
app.rdg: Fashion or Folly, Vanity or Taste—
Fashion or Folly, Vanity or Taste—

lg.l: Thou, whose high Laws, rever’d by Courtly Dames!

app.lem: Cecil’s hereditary Wisdom frames.—William Cecil, Lord Burghley (1520-98) was an advisor to Elizabeth I, and his descendent, Brownlow Cecil, the ninth Earl of Exeter (1725-93), advised King George III. According to Judith Thompson, the references to fashion can be interpreted as a statement by Thelwall that the hereditary wisdom once available in the counsel offered by the Cecil family has degraded.
app.rdg: Cecil’s hereditary Wisdom frames.—
Cecil’s hereditary Wisdom frames.—

lg.l: Important Guardian of a Royal Court!

app.lem: Imperial Grandeur’s wisest; best support!
app.rdg: Imperial Grandeur’s wisest; best support!
Imperial Grandeur’s wisest, best, support!

lg.l: Whose awful Nod prescribes the Mantua’s grace,
And dooms, without appeal, in Gloves and Lace,
When, Wand in Hand, on Birth-Days, he presides,

app.lem: And with the Best of Kings, the sway divides!—
app.rdg: And with the BEST OF KINGS, the sway divides!—
And with the Best of Kings the sway divides!—

app.lem: —That Best of Kings, from whom what blessings flow!
app.rdg: —That BEST OF KINGS, from whom what blessings flow!
—That Best of Kings, from whom what blessings flow!

lg.l: Who for his People keeps a Raree-Show
Of Pictures fine, a Month each Year, or more:
But makes them drop their Shillings at the Door!—

app.lem: That Best of Kings, who gives his Royal Name
app.rdg: That BEST OF KINGS, who gives his Royal Name
That Best of kings, who gives his Royal Name

lg.l: To every Work of Charity, or Fame;
But, liberal as he is, with Prudence blest,
Keeps the Subscription Guinea in his Chest.—

app.lem: That Best of Kings, who, Umpire of the Arts!
app.rdg: That BEST OF KINGS, who, Umpire of the Arts!
That Best of Kings, who, Umpire of the Arts!

app.lem: To West’s coarse outline his first Smile imparts:—
app.rdg: To West’s coarse outline his first Smile imparts:—
To West’s coarse outline his first Smile imparts;—

app.lem: West, from whose hand each Male Complexion shines
app.rdg: West, from whose hand each Male Complexion shines
West, from whose hand each Male Complexion shines

lg.l: Like half-wrought Copper from our Cornish Mines;
While, smooth as wax, each female Cheek is spread,
And every Lip, with the same lifeless red!—

app.lem: West, whose long Groups, in order’d Rows display’d,
app.rdg: West, whose long Groups, in order’d Rows display’d,
West, whose long Groups, in order’d Rows display’d,

app.lem: (As ranks of Soldiers strut on the parade,)
app.rdg: (As ranks of Soldiers strut on the parade,)
(As ranks of soldiers strut on the parade,)

lg.l: At Knightly Installations, make us stare,

app.lem: And ask What Corporal drill’d the noble Fair!—
app.rdg: And ask What Corporal drill’d the noble Fair!—
And ask What Corporal drill’d the noble Fair!—

app.lem: West, who, not only taught to husband Time,
app.rdg: West, who, not only taught to husband Time,
West, who, not only taught to husband Time,

lg.l: Maintains the loss of Space an equal Crime,
So fills—despite of ease and simple grace—

app.lem: Each Inch of Canvas with a varnish’d Face,Benjamin West (1738-1820) was an American painter. His art is here satirized as being flat, with the bodies of people clustered, as he attempts to cover each inch of canvas. In P, this line read So fills each Scrap Of Canvas with a Face,. Since this is a line on a pasted page in the DM, Thelwall’s changes are scribbled in on top of the printed page. Inch is not capitalized or underlined (for italicization) in DM, but we have edited it to match the structure of P’s Scrap of Canvas. Since Thelwall scribbled in inch in the small margin between lines, he could not indicate how he wanted it presented. Thus, editorial liberties have been taken to maintain a uniform presentation.
app.rdg: So fills each Scrap inch of Canvas with a varnish’d Face,
So fills each Scrap of Canvas with a Face,

lg.l: Which all, lest quarrels rise for shape and air,
The self-same attitude and features share—

app.lem: West, who, to Scripture rules devoutly true,
app.rdg: West, who, to Scripture rules devoutly true,
West, who, to Scripture rules devoutly true,

lg.l: Thinks Eye for Eye, and Tooth for Tooth, are due,
And painting Pharoah, and his warlike host

l.hi: O’erthown by Moses, and in Soap Suds lost,

app.lem: With vengeful Brush, for Justice, arms his Hands,
app.rdg: With vengeful Brush, for Justice, arms his Hands,
With vengeful Brush, for Justice, arms his Hands,

lg.l: And murders Moses, as the Law commands.—Possibly an allusion to West’s painting Pharoah and his Host Lost in the Red Sea (1792).

app.lem: That West, who, lest the first sad Curse be vain,
app.rdg: That West, who, lest the first sad Curse be vain,
That West, who, lest the first sad Curse be vain,

lg.l: Damns our fall’n Parents, o’er and o’er again;

app.lem: Then, fired with Zeal, instructs his glorious Son
app.rdg: Then, fired with Zeal, instructs his glorious SON
Then, fired with Zeal, instructs his glorious Son

lg.l: (By whom one Day the Sire shall be outdone)
To force grim Satan from the depths of Hell,
’Midst grinning Forms of Ridicule to dwell,
Where laughing Scorn shall more afflict his Pride
Than all the Flames for torturing Ages tried.

app.lem: Genius of Britain!—That same Nymph I mean
app.rdg: GENIUS of BRITAIN!—That same Nymph I mean
Genius of Britain!—That same Nymph I mean

app.lem: Who teaches Tambour to our Gracious Queen;
app.rdg: Who teaches Tambour to our GRACIOUS QUEEN;
Who teaches Tambour to our Gracious Queen;

app.lem: Whence from her Needle (wond’rous Art!) arise
app.rdg: Whence from her Needle (wond’rous Art!) arise
Whence from her Needle (wondrous Art!) arise

lg.l: Long Pomps of Silken Trees, and Worsted Skies;
Quadrupeds, non-descript, are forc’d to Fame,

app.lem: Plants with new forms, and Flowers without a name:
app.rdg: Plants with new forms, and Flowers without a name:
Plants with new forms, and Flowers without a name;

lg.l: Or, soaring higher, to the Human form,
Her steel-eyed Pencil, (exquisitely warm!)
Calls faces forth—(if those who late have seen
Laurence’s Portrait of that awful Mien

For such a Fact can take a Poet’s word!)Sir Thomas Lawrence (1769–1830) was a painter. The painting referenced here of Queen Charlotte is likely the one he was commissioned to do between 1789 and 1790.
Still more unmeaning than her Royal Lord!
—Prudent Amusement for a married Dame
Whose Numerous Babes her frugal Fondness claim!
Expensive Books might shrink her little Store,

app.lem: Concerts and Treats make even the Wealthy poor:In the DM, the v of even is hand-written by Thelwall onto the cut and pasted page; in P, it is spelled e’en. While we have chosen the DM in this instance, we acknowledge that it is a strange change, since it disrupts the strict iambic pentameter of the line. The disruption of the earlier metre may reflect Thelwall’s later prosodic theories and abandonment of poetic contradictions but he does not do this consistently.
app.rdg: Concerts and Treats make e ’ v en the Wealthy poor:
Concerts and Treats make e’en the Wealthy poor:

lg.l: But she at home who o’er her Needle dreams,
Or patches Fragments up with frugal Seams,

app.lem: Or works old Sattin Satin Coats with Colours fine,
app.rdg: Or works old Sattin Coats with Colours fine,
Or works old Satin Coats with Colours fine,

lg.l: O’er no Upholsterer’s hideous Bill shall pine;
Yet sees, blest Harvest of her Royal Cares!
Quilts for her Beds, and Covers for her Chairs.

app.lem: Genius of Britain! who, with like control,
app.rdg: GENIUS of BRITAIN! who, with like control,
Genius of Britain! who, with like control,

app.lem: Sway George’s, Charlotte’s, West’s, and Warren’s Soul!—The references to George and Charlotte here are obviously to King George III (1738-1820) and his wife Queen Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz (1744–1818), who ruled at the time of the poem’s composition. The earlier reference to the Gracious Queen (line 148 of Canto One) is also to Charlotte, who was known for her needle work. According to Judith Thompson, Warren refers to Dr. Richard Warren, a physician who had helped treating George III’s illness during the Regency Crisis of 1788: see P, note 197.
app.rdg: Sway GEORGE’s, CHARLOTTE’s, WEST’s, and WARREN’s Soul!—
Sway George’s, Charlotte’s, West’s, and Warren’s Soul!—

app.lem: Make Merry’s ravings, Coleman’s stolen trash,For Merry, see notes 39 and 41. Thelwall parodies one of Merry’s poems—The Laurel of Liberty—at the end of the Epic Poetry chapter in P. Coleman refers to two people: Colman the elder (1732-94) and the younger (1762-1836), both playwrights and theatre managers. In the Prefatory Memoir of Poems Chiefly Written in Retirement, Thelwall mentions that free use (xxi) had been made of some of his work. This suggests he may have been complaining of plagiarism in this line.
app.rdg: Make MERRY’s ravings, COLEMAN’s stolen trash,
Make Merry’s ravings, Coleman’s stolen trash,

app.lem: His Tragi-Comic-Pantomimic hash,
app.rdg: His Tragi-Comic-Pantomimic hash,
His Tragi-Comic-Pantomimic hash,

app.lem: Pass for true Wit! assist my Epic Lay:
app.rdg: Pass for true Wit! assist my EPIC LAY:
Pass for true Wit! assist my Epic Lay:

app.lem: And I may hope to write as well as they!In P, the last line of the Invocation reads For hard the Task my vent’rous Lines essay. In DM, Thelwall has crossed out the original line and written his correction underneath. His change makes absolutely clear the satiric nature of the poem.

subst.del: For hard the Task my vent’rous Lines essay.
subst.add: And I may hope to write as well as they!

app.rdg: For hard the Task my vent’rous Lines essay.
